Introduction

Dermatophyte infections are a group of common superficial fungal infections caused primarily by filamentous fungi of the Trichophyton (eg, Trichophyton rubrum), Epidermophyton, and Microsporum genera.  These disorders, also known as tinea infections, are categorized primarily by location, and include:



  • Tinea corporis (body), also called ringworm
  • Tinea capitis (scalp)
  • Tinea pedis (foot)
  • Tinea cruris (groin), also called jock itch
  • Tinea unguium (nails), also called onychomycosis
  • Tinea barbae (beard area)

Pathophysiology



Dermatophyte organisms are ubiquitous, occurring in both indoor and outdoor environments.  Transmission readily occurs through direct contact with soil, contaminated surfaces, or infected animals or people or via fomites (eg, shared combs for tinea capitis).  Autoinoculation (eg, from a different body site) also occurs.



Dermatophytes produce keratinases that break down keratin, allowing the fungi to invade and proliferate in keratinized tissues such as skin, hair, and nails.  The infection typically remains localized to the stratum corneum, rarely penetrating the dermis or subcutaneous tissues.  Disruption of the normal keratin structure leads to the characteristic scaling and flaking seen in these disorders.  The immune response to the fungal antigens contributes to the inflammation and bothersome symptoms (eg, pruritus) observed in dermatophyte infections.



Occasionally, dermatophyte infections can trigger an immune-mediated autoeczematous phenomenon (ie, dermatophytid reaction) in nearby or remote uninfected skin.  Findings include an erythematous, papulosquamous rash, sometimes with bullae formation.

Risk factors



  • Environmental factors:  warm, humid climates; communal bathing areas
  • Personal habits:  poor hygiene; excessive sweating; close-fitting, nonbreathable clothing
  • Immunosuppression:  diabetes mellitus, HIV/AIDS, use of immunosuppressive drugs (extensive, widespread involvement should raise concern for compromised immunity)
  • Genetic predisposition:  family history of dermatophyte infections
  • Occupational exposure:  farmers, athletes, military personnel

Pathology



Histopathologically, dermatophyte infections demonstrate hyphae within the stratum corneum (

image 1
), accompanied by hyperkeratosis, parakeratosis, and mild to moderate inflammatory infiltrate in the epidermis and dermis.  The inflammation can be more pronounced in tinea capitis and tinea barbae, with potential formation of kerions (boggy masses) due to an intense immune response.

Clinical presentation



Tinea corporis:  annular, erythematous plaques with central clearing and a raised, scaly border (

image 2
).  Lesions are often pruritic and can spread peripherally.



Tinea capitis:  scaly patches with hair loss (

image 3
), black dots (broken hair shafts), or kerion formation (inflammatory, boggy masses).  Cervical lymphadenopathy may be present.



Tinea cruris:  erythematous plaques with well-demarcated, scaly borders (

image 4
) in the groin area, often bilateral but sparing the scrotum.



Tinea unguium (onychomycosis):  thickened, discolored (

image 5
), brittle nails with subungual debris.  Onycholysis (separation of the nail from the nail bed) may occur.



Tinea barbae:  erythematous, scaly plaques in the beard area (

image 6
), potentially with pustules, folliculitis, and crusting.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis is based primarily on clinical features but should be supported when possible by potassium hydroxide (KOH) microscopy, which reveals fungal hyphae.  Supplemental evaluation may include:



  • Fungal culture:  identification of dermatophyte species from cultured specimens
  • Wood lamp examination:  useful in diagnosing tinea capitis caused by certain species that emit fluorescence under ultraviolet light
  • Histopathology:  skin biopsy showing fungal elements in the stratum corneum

Differential diagnosis



  • Psoriasis:  presents with well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales (
    image 7
    ), typically on extensor surfaces and the scalp.  Unlike tinea lesions, psoriasis lesions are not annular and do not have central clearing.
  • Seborrheic dermatitis:  erythematous, scaly patches (
    image 8
    ), often in sebaceous areas (eg, scalp, ears, face).  Unlike tinea lesions, seborrheic dermatitis lesions typically lack the annular shape and central clearing.
  • Eczema (atopic dermatitis):  pruritic, erythematous patches with vesicles and oozing.  Chronic lesions may become lichenified
    image 9
    ).  Lesions are usually less well-defined than in dermatophyte infection and are typically not annular (except in nummular eczema subtype).  Most patients have a history of other atopic disorders (eg, asthma, seasonal allergies).
  • Pityriasis rosea:  a sef-limited inflammatory disorder that starts with a solitary, erythematous macule or plaque known as a herald patch (
    image 10
    ), followed by a broader eruption of scaly, ovoid plaques, often in a Christmas-tree pattern on the trunk (
    image 11
    ).  Unlike in tinea, lesions are typically not pruritic and resolve spontaneously.
  • Contact dermatitis:  erythematous, vesiculobullous (
    image 12
    ), pruritic rash in areas of contact with allergens or irritants.  Distribution pattern and history of exposure help differentiate contact dermatitis from tinea.
  • Nail dystrophies:  various disorders (eg, trauma, lichen planus, psoriasis) can cause thickening and distortion of the nail plate that mimic onychomycosis but lack fungal elements on KOH microscopy.

Management

Antifungals



  • Topical antifungals:  first-line therapy for localized tinea infection.  Common agents include clotrimazole, terbinafine, miconazole, and ketoconazole (nystatin, which is effective against Candida, is not effective against dermatophytes).
  • Systemic antifungals:  required for extensive involvement, tinea capitis, tinea barbae, and moderate to severe onychomycosis.  Options include terbinafine, itraconazole, fluconazole, and griseofulvin


The preferred agents and duration of therapy are determined by the specific clinical syndrome; several weeks of treatment may be required, and some systemic medications require liver function test monitoring.

Adjunctive therapies



Keratolytics (eg, urea, salicylic acid) can be considered to remove scale and enhance penetration of topical agents.

Preventive measures



Keeping affected areas dry, avoiding shared personal items, and treating infected pets are recommended measures.  Foot powders and antifungal sprays can help prevent recurrence in tinea pedis.

Complications



  • Secondary bacterial infections, especially in tinea pedis
  • Chronicity and recurrence, particularly in onychomycosis
  • Permanent scarring or hair loss (tinea capitis)
  • Nail dystrophy (onychomycosis)
  • Spread to other body areas (autoinoculation) or close contacts

Prognosis



With appropriate treatment, dermatophyte infections generally have a good prognosis.  Recurrence is common, particularly in the presence of predisposing factors, but adherence to preventive measures can significantly reduce the risk.

Summary



Dermatophyte infections encompass a variety of conditions affecting the skin, hair, and nails; these are caused by fungi that thrive on keratin.  The diagnosis is based primarily on clinical evaluation but should be confirmed by potassium hydroxide microscopy when possible.  Appropriate antifungal treatment is usually effective, but recurrence is common.
